full_text: Succeed Insurance requires that a reserve in the amount of $2,000 be automatically set aside for exposures associated with injury incidents on general liability policies. I will navigate to the reserve creation rules. Here, I observe that none of the existing reserve creation rules relate specifically to injury exposure types. So I'll create a new rule. I'll give the rule a descriptive name, using the SI for Succeed Insurance Code. And add a description. The loss type is liability. The loss type is liability. And the rule only applies to general liability policies. I don't need a rule variable, but I do need a rule condition. The requirement is that there should be an injury incident on the exposure. I could use the does not equal operator and set the right expression to null, but it's simpler to use the has a value operator. Finally, I need an action to create the reserve. The reserve will be for claim cost. For medical costs. And the amount of the reserve is $2,000. This completes the rule so I will save it. Then return to it. So I can stage it. And approve it. Now I'll create a general liability claim to test the rule. I select a general liability customer. The claim is reported by Hans Molman. Hans is the claimant. A brick fell out of the wall and hit Hans in the head. This happened at the company headquarters. Now I'll add details of the injury. For purposes of this demonstration, Hans is a third party. The brick fall resulted in a minor concussion, which is a moderate injury. This is all the information I need at this time. I'll add an exposure associated with the injury incident. This exposure is for general liability medical payments. This is a very important thing. I'll assign the claim to myself and finish it. Now when I visit the claim. If I look at its financials page. I see the $2,000 medical payment reserve the rule created. This completes the creating and testing a reserve business rule demonstration. segments.text: Succeed Insurance requires that a reserve in the amount of $2,000 be automatically set aside for exposures associated with injury incidents on general liability policies. I will navigate to the reserve creation rules. Here, I observe that none of the existing reserve creation rules relate specifically to injury exposure types. So I'll create a new rule.
I'll give the rule a descriptive name, using the SI for Succeed Insurance Code.
And add a description.
The loss type is liability.
The loss type is liability.
And the rule only applies to general liability policies.
I don't need a rule variable, but I do need a rule condition.
The requirement is that there should be an injury incident on the exposure.
I could use the does not equal operator and set the right expression to null, but it's simpler to use the has a value operator.
Finally, I need an action to create the reserve.
The reserve will be for claim cost.
For medical costs.
And the amount of the reserve is $2,000.
This completes the rule so I will save it.
Then return to it.
So I can stage it.
And approve it.
Now I'll create a general liability claim to test the rule.
I select a general liability customer.
The claim is reported by Hans Molman.
Hans is the claimant.
A brick fell out of the wall and hit Hans in the head.
This happened at the company headquarters.
Now I'll add details of the injury.
For purposes of this demonstration, Hans is a third party.
The brick fall resulted in a minor concussion, which is a moderate injury.
This is all the information I need at this time.
I'll add an exposure associated with the injury incident.
This exposure is for general liability medical payments.
This is a very important thing.
I'll assign the claim to myself and finish it.
Now when I visit the claim.
If I look at its financials page.
I see the $2,000 medical payment reserve the rule created.
This completes the creating and testing a reserve business rule demonstration.
